Class GuiRoot

java.lang.Object
org.example.galaxy_trucker.View.GUI.GuiRoot
All Implemented Interfaces:
View
public class GuiRoot extends Object implements View
The `GuiRoot` class is responsible for handling the graphical user interface (GUI) and interaction logic for the game application. It manages the primary stage, scene graph components, game state updates, and player interactions within the UI. The class interfaces with various game events (e.g., `ReconnectedEvent`, `TileEvent`, `HandEvent`) to dynamically update the visuals and state of the game in response to player actions or server events. It ensures thread-safe updates using the JavaFX `Platform.runLater` method and provides interactive elements for players to engage with the game. Key responsibilities of the `GuiRoot` class include: - Setting up the JavaFX application window (`sceneSetup`). - Managing reconnection processes and restoring player state (`reconnect`). - Updating game boards, personal boards, or specific player-related UI elements (`updateBoard`, `updateOthersPB`). - Handling tile interactions, including placement, removal, or tiling mechanics (`updateBoard`, `updateHand`, `updateUncoveredTilesSet`). - Monitoring and processing various game events to reflect gameplay dynamics. Class fields: - `guiThread`: The thread in which the GUI is executed. - `primaryStage`: The primary stage for the JavaFX application. - `inputQueue`: Queue for processing player inputs. - `primaryRoot`, `contentRoot`, `primaryScene`: JavaFX scene components for rendering and layout structure. - `playerClient`: The client handling communication with the server. - `printer`: Utility responsible for logging and message display. - `lobbyEvents`, `myGameName`, `myName`, `myGameLv`: Fields to manage lobby and game session information. - `readyPlayers`, `amIReady`, `amIBuilding`: Fields tracking player readiness and game phases. - `players`, `discardedTiles`, `discardedMap`: Structures for managing player and tile-related data. - `gameBoardImg`, `myBoard`, `tilePlaceholder`, `tileImage`: UI elements for displaying game and player boards. - Numerous other fields to handle UI components related to game mechanics, interactivity, animations, and events. Methods: - `GuiRoot(LoginClient loginClient)`: Constructor initializing the GUI with the user's login client. - `void setStage(Stage primaryStage)`: Sets the primary stage for the application. - `void sceneSetup()`: Configures the JavaFX scene graph and initializes the application's opening view. - `void reconnect(ReconnectedEvent event)`: Handles reconnection events, showing a success dialog and restoring game state. - `void updateBoard(TileEvent event)`: Updates the game board UI to reflect changes based on a tile event. - `void updateOthersPB(PlayerTileEvent event)`: Updates the personal boards of other players based on a player tile event. - `void updateHand(HandEvent event)`: Updates the currently active tile in the player's hand. - `void updateUncoveredTilesSet(UncoverdTileSetEvent event)`: Updates the UI for uncovered tiles, including managing discarded tiles and their interactions. The implementation ensures seamless and fluid user experiences, maintaining thread safety by leveraging the JavaFX `Platform.runLater` method for any UI modifications. This class provides the backbone for the visual and interactive components of the application.

  • Method Details

    • setStage

      public void setStage(javafx.stage.Stage primaryStage)
      Sets the primary stage for the application and updates the stage in the printer.
      Parameters:
      primaryStage - the primary Stage object to be set and used throughout the application

    • sceneSetup

      public void sceneSetup()
      Initializes and sets up the main application scene. This method is executed on the JavaFX application thread using `Platform.runLater`. It prepares the primary scene and its associated components such as the root pane, the content pane, the tile image, background media, and binds necessary properties for dynamic adjustment with the primary stage's dimensions. The scene is finalized by invoking the `goToFirstScene` method to transition to the initial scene.

      Parameters:

    • askInput

      The input retrieved from the inputQueue, or an empty string if an interruption occurs.

    • reconnect

      public void reconnect(ReconnectedEvent event)
      Handles player reconnection by displaying a success dialog and restoring game state. This method performs two key functions:
      • Displays a modal confirmation dialog on successful reconnection
      • Restores the player's game state from the reconnection event

      UI Behavior:

      • Creates a modal dialog titled "Reconnection"
      • Displays success message with standard styling
      • Provides an exit button using the shared button maker utility
      • Blocks interaction with parent window until dismissed
      • Ensures thread-safe UI operations via Platform.runLater()

      State Restoration:

      • Updates player name from event.getPlayerId()
      • Updates game name from event.getGameId()
      • Updates game level from event.getLv()
      • Sets reconnecting flag to true for phase handling
      • Only executes restoration if playerId is not null
      Specified by:
      reconnect in interface View
      Parameters:
      event - The ReconnectedEvent containing reconnection details:
      • playerId - The reconnected player's identifier
      • gameId - The game identifier being rejoined
      • lv - The game level (1 or 2)
      See Also:
      • ReconnectedEvent
      • Platform.runLater(Runnable)
      • Modality.WINDOW_MODAL
      • goBackButtonMaker(Stage)

    • updateBoard

      public void updateBoard(TileEvent event)
      Updates the game board UI to reflect a new tile placement or modification received via a TileEvent.

      This method handles a wide range of tile update scenarios, including:

      • Placing a new tile image on the board based on the tile ID and rotation.
      • Rendering alien crew members, human crew, cargo, and batteries over tiles.
      • Managing interactivity for specific tile types during different game phases (e.g., building, cargo handling, theft, selection).
      • Updating the internal list of excludedTiles depending on the tile content.
      • Handling special buffer tile cases at fixed coordinates (3,8) and (3,9).
      If the tile includes interactive elements (e.g., crew or cargo), appropriate mouse event handlers are attached to support gameplay mechanics like removal, cargo selection, theft, or special commands.

      Tile updates are applied on the JavaFX Application Thread using Platform.runLater() to safely manipulate UI components.

      Specified by:
      updateBoard in interface View
      Parameters:
      event - the TileEvent carrying all necessary data for rendering and interactivity, including tile ID, coordinates, rotation, and contents such as aliens, crew, cargo, or batteries

    • updateOthersPB

      public void updateOthersPB(PlayerTileEvent event)
      Updates the personal board (PB) UI of another player based on a PlayerTileEvent.

      This method handles the display of another player's board state by rendering tile images along with any associated game elements such as aliens, human crew, cargo, or batteries. If the player's board has not been displayed before, a new GridPane is created for them.

      UI components are updated on the JavaFX Application Thread using Platform.runLater(Runnable).

      Displayed elements may include:

      • Aliens: Brown or purple alien images layered on the tile.
      • Humans: A row of small crew images.
      • Cargo: A clickable cargo icon that opens a dialog showing cargo contents.
      • Batteries: Battery icons displayed with reduced tile opacity.
      Specified by:
      updateOthersPB in interface View
      Parameters:
      event - the PlayerTileEvent containing the player name, tile position, tile ID, and any additional elements (aliens, crew, cargo, batteries)

    • updateHand

      public void updateHand(HandEvent event)
      Updates the currently held tile in the player's hand based on the HandEvent.

      This method sets the tile image to either a placeholder (when the tile ID is 158, indicating an empty or removed tile) or to the corresponding tile image from resources. It also resets the rotation to 0 and ensures the visual opacity is appropriate:

      • 0.5 opacity for placeholder tiles (ID 158)
      • Full opacity (1.0) for active/valid tiles

      UI updates are executed on the JavaFX Application Thread using Platform.runLater(Runnable).

      Specified by:
      updateHand in interface View
      Parameters:
      event - the HandEvent containing the tile ID for the new tile to be displayed in the player's hand

    • updateCoveredTilesSet

      public void updateCoveredTilesSet(CoveredTileSetEvent event)
      Description copied from interface: View
      Updates the state of the covered tiles set in the view based on the provided event. This method processes the provided {CoveredTileSetEvent} instance to update relevant information in the user interface, reflecting changes in the covered tiles set.
      Specified by:
      updateCoveredTilesSet in interface View
      Parameters:
      event - the event containing information related to the covered tiles set state, such as the updated size of the set.

    • updateUncoveredTilesSet

      public void updateUncoveredTilesSet(UncoverdTileSetEvent event)
      Updates the UI to reflect the current state of the set of uncovered (discarded or available) tiles.

      If the tile with the given ID already exists in the discarded map, it will be removed from both the `uncoveredTiles` UI container and the internal tracking structures (`discardedMap`, `discardedTiles`).

      If the tile is not yet in the discarded map, it will be created as an ImageView, styled, wrapped in a VBox, and added to both the internal tracking structures and the UI container. A mouse click on the tile will queue a "PickTile" command with the index of that tile.

      All UI updates are safely wrapped inside Platform.runLater(Runnable) to ensure execution on the JavaFX Application Thread.

      Specified by:
      updateUncoveredTilesSet in interface View
      Parameters:
      event - the UncoverdTileSetEvent containing the ID of the tile to update

    • showDeck

      public void showDeck(DeckEvent event)
      Displays a modal window showing a set of cards from the deck, typically used when spying the deck.

      The method creates a new Stage and populates it with card images based on the IDs received in the DeckEvent. Specific ID ranges are handled with custom images:

      • IDs between 29 and 35 are displayed as "open space" cards.
      • IDs 38 and 39 are displayed as "stardust" cards.
      • Other IDs are mapped to corresponding image files using their numeric value.

      A button labeled "Ok" is included to close the window. All card images are displayed in a horizontal layout and are scaled to a consistent width while maintaining aspect ratio.

      All UI updates are wrapped in Platform.runLater(Runnable) to ensure execution on the JavaFX Application Thread.

      Specified by:
      showDeck in interface View
      Parameters:
      event - the DeckEvent containing a list of card IDs to be shown

    • showCard

      public void showCard(CardEvent event)
      Displays the appropriate card image based on the given CardEvent and sets up the number of planets to display for planet choice cards.

      The method handles different types of cards:

      • Open Space cards (IDs 29-35) - displays a generic open space image
      • Stardust cards (IDs 38-39) - displays a stardust image
      • Other cards - displays the specific card image corresponding to the event ID

      For planet choice cards (IDs 21-28), this method also sets the number of planets that will be available for selection:

      • 4 planets for cards 21 and 27
      • 3 planets for cards 22, 24, 25, and 28
      • 2 planets for cards 23 and 26
      Specified by:
      showCard in interface View
      Parameters:
      event - The CardEvent containing the card ID to display. The card image is determined based on this ID.

    • disconnect

      public void disconnect()
      Handles disconnection by showing a modal dialog with options to reconnect or exit. This method must be called on the JavaFX Application Thread, as it creates UI elements.

      When invoked, this method:

      • Creates a modal dialog titled "Connection lost"
      • Displays a message and two buttons: "Reconnect" and "Exit"
      • Adds the corresponding action ("Reconnect" or "Exit") to the inputQueue when a button is clicked
      • Blocks interaction with the parent window (primaryStage) until resolved

      The dialog is created and shown using Platform.runLater() to ensure thread safety with the JavaFX Application Thread. The method follows the WINDOW_MODAL modality pattern, meaning it only blocks the owning window (primaryStage) while allowing interaction with other application windows.

      Specified by:
      disconnect in interface View

    • connect

      public void connect() throws IOException
      Description copied from interface: View
      Establishes a connection between the view and its corresponding client or server infrastructure. This method should be called to initiate the necessary communication channels for the view to function.
      Specified by:
      connect in interface View
      Throws:
      IOException - if an I/O error occurs while trying to connect.

    • setGameboard

      public void setGameboard(int lv)
      Initializes and displays the game board based on the specified level. This method must be called on the JavaFX Application Thread as it updates UI elements.

      The method performs the following actions:

      • Sets the current game level (myGameLv) to the specified level
      • Loads the appropriate game assets based on the level:
        • For level 1: loads level 1 game board image, card back image, and calls Lv1GameboardSetup()
        • For level 2: loads level 2 game board image, card back image, and calls Lv2GameboardSetup()
      • Creates and displays the game board stage by calling setGameBoardStage()

      All UI operations are wrapped in Platform.runLater() to ensure thread safety with the JavaFX Application Thread.

      Specified by:
      setGameboard in interface View
      Parameters:
      lv - The game level to set up (1 or 2). Any other value will default to level 2 behavior.

    • checkValidityScene

      public void checkValidityScene()
      Creates and displays a scene for validating and removing invalid tiles from the game board. This interactive scene allows players to:
      • Identify and remove invalid tiles from their board
      • View other players' boards
      • Complete the building phase with level-specific options

      Key features:

      • Displays a prominent "Remove Invalid Tiles!" prompt with golden text
      • Makes valid tiles clickable for removal (sends "RemoveTile X Y" to inputQueue)
      • Excludes tiles marked in excludedTiles from being interactive
      • Provides different completion behavior based on game level:
        • Level 1: Simple "FinishBuilding" command
        • Level 2: Opens a position selection dialog (1-4) before sending "FinishBuilding X"
      • Displays other players' boards for reference
      • Includes a game board preview that can be clicked to show the full game board

      The scene layout includes:

      • Left: Current player's board with interactive tiles
      • Center: Action buttons and game board preview
      • Right: Other players' boards

    • choosePosition

      public void choosePosition()
      Updates the user interface to prompt the user to choose a position for their valid ship. This method is executed on the JavaFX Application Thread using Platform.runLater to ensure thread safety when updating the UI.

    • AddCrewScene

      public void AddCrewScene()
      Creates and displays the crew placement scene where players can add crew members to their ship. This interactive scene allows players to:
      • Select different crew types (human, purple alien, brown alien - level 2 only)
      • Place selected crew members on valid tiles of their board
      • View other players' boards for reference

      Key features:

      • Displays a prominent "Populate Your Ship!" prompt with golden text
      • Provides crew selection panel with clickable crew member images
      • Makes valid board tiles clickable for placement (sends commands to inputQueue)
      • Excludes tiles marked in excludedTiles from being interactive
      • Shows different crew options based on game level:
        • Level 1: Only human crew members available
        • Level 2: Human, purple alien, and brown alien crew members available
      • Displays other players' boards in a separate panel

      The scene layout includes:

      • Left: Current player's board with interactive tiles
      • Center: Crew selection panel (right of player's board)
      • Right: Other players' boards
      • Bottom: Action prompt with decorative background

      State management:

      • Sets amIBuilding flag to false
      • Sets checkvalidity flag to false
      • Uses AtomicReference to track currently selected crew type
      See Also:
      • GridPane
      • Platform.runLater(Runnable)
      • AtomicReference

    • showLobby

      public void showLobby(LobbyEvent event)
      Displays the game lobby interface where players can create or join games. This method handles both the initial lobby display and dynamic updates when lobby events occur.

      The lobby provides:

      • A list of available games with their players
      • Options to create new games or reconnect to existing ones
      • Dynamic updates when players join/create games

      Key components:

      • Game List:
        • Displays all active games with their IDs and player lists
        • Each entry has a "Join" button
        • Updates automatically when receiving LobbyEvents
      • New Game Button:
        • Opens a form to create a new game
        • Collects: player name, game name, game mode (Tutorial/Complete), max players
        • Validates inputs before sending creation request
      • Reconnect Button:
        • Allows reconnection using a session token
        • Validates token before sending reconnect request

      Behavior details:

      • Processes incoming LobbyEvents to add/remove games from the list
      • Maintains lobbyEvents collection to track current game states
      • Uses modal dialogs for game creation and reconnection
      • Enforces input validation (e.g., name length limits)
      • Routes all actions through the inputQueue
      Specified by:
      showLobby in interface View
      Parameters:
      event - The LobbyEvent triggering the update (new game created or player joined)

    • showLobbyGame

      public void showLobbyGame(GameLobbyEvent event)
      Displays the lobby game interface by updating the list of players and their readiness status. Updates the visual representation of player names and readiness using JavaFX components.
      Specified by:
      showLobbyGame in interface View
      Parameters:
      event - the GameLobbyEvent containing the list of players, their readiness status, and other data related to the game lobby.

    • LobbyGameScreen

      public void LobbyGameScreen()
      Creates and displays the in-game lobby screen where players can prepare before the game starts. This screen shows player readiness status and provides game management options.

      The screen includes:

      • Game name display (styled with golden text)
      • List of players and their readiness status (via readyPlayers ListView)
      • Interactive controls:
        • Ready/Not Ready toggle button
        • Quit game button (with confirmation dialog)
        • Debug ship buttons (only in level 2)

      Key functionality:

      • Ready Button:
        • Toggles between "Ready!" and "Not Ready" states
        • Sends "Ready" command to inputQueue when clicked
        • Updates based on amIReady flag
      • Quit Button:
        • Opens a confirmation dialog before quitting
        • Sends "Quit" command to inputQueue when confirmed
      • Debug Buttons (Level 2 only):
        • "Debug Ship 1" sends "DebugShip 0" command
        • "Debug Ship 2" sends "DebugShip 1" command
        • Buttons disable after use

      Layout details:

      • Responsive design bound to primaryStage dimensions
      • Game name at top center
      • Player list below game name
      • Control buttons centered at bottom

    • updateGameboard

      public void updateGameboard(GameBoardEvent event)
      Updates the visual representation of player positions on the game board. This method handles both adding/removing players and updating their positions based on incoming GameBoardEvents.

      Behavior details:

      • For new players (not in playerPositions):
        • Adds their position to playerPositions map
        • Adds their rocket visualization to rocketsPane
      • When position is -1 (player leaving):
        • Removes player from playerPositions map
        • Removes their rocket from rocketsPane
      • For position updates:
        • Calculates screen coordinates using pre-defined coords list
        • Applies 85% scaling factor to match game board scaling
        • Adjusts position by -20 pixels to center the rocket image

      Thread safety:

      • All UI operations are wrapped in Platform.runLater()
      • Safely handles concurrent modifications to playerPositions
      Specified by:
      updateGameboard in interface View
      Parameters:
      event - The GameBoardEvent containing:
      • playerID - Unique identifier for the player
      • position - New board position (-1 indicates removal)

    • rewardsChanged

      public void rewardsChanged(RewardsEvent event)
      Handles changes in rewards when a RewardsEvent occurs. Updates the current cargo image, coordinates, rewards list, and remaining rewards count, and initiates cargo handling.
      Specified by:
      rewardsChanged in interface View
      Parameters:
      event - the RewardsEvent containing details about the updated rewards

    • buildingScene

      public void buildingScene()
      Creates and displays the ship building scene where players construct their spaceships. This interactive scene provides all necessary tools for tile management and ship construction.

      The scene includes:

      • Game Information:
        • Game name display (styled with golden text)
        • Preview of the game board
      • Tile Management:
        • Current tile display with rotation controls (90° clockwise/counter-clockwise)
        • "Pick Tile" and "Discard" buttons
        • Two tile buffers with hover effects
        • Hourglass button (level 2 only) for special actions
      • Player Boards:
        • Current player's board (interactive)
        • Other players' boards (view-only)
      • Card Decks (level 2 only):
        • Three face-down decks that can be inspected
      • Completion Controls:
        • Level 1: Simple "Done!" button
        • Level 2: Position selection dialog (1-4) before completion

      Interactive Features:

      • Tile Rotation:
        • Clockwise and counter-clockwise rotation buttons
        • Maintains rotation state in tileRotation variable
      • Tile Buffers:
        • Visual hover effects (opacity changes)
        • Sends "ToBuffer 0" or "ToBuffer 1" commands when clicked
      • Action Buttons:
        • All buttons send commands to inputQueue
        • Includes validation for required selections (level 2 position)

      Layout Organization:

      • Left: Uncovered tiles scroll pane (40% opacity)
      • Center: Main building area with player board and controls
      • Right: Other players' boards
      • Responsive design bound to primaryStage dimensions

    • flightScene

      public void flightScene()
      Creates and displays the flight phase scene showing ship status and interactive elements. This scene provides real-time information about the player's ship and allows interaction during the flight phase of the game.

      The scene includes:

      • Ship Statistics Panel displaying:
        • Cannons (Attack power)
        • Engines (Speed)
        • Energy
        • Human crew
        • Damage tokens
        • Credits
      • Card Display Area showing:
        • Current card (face-up)
        • Deck (face-down)
      • Interactive Elements:
        • Clickable tiles on player's board (when enabled)
        • Game board preview button
        • Phase-specific action buttons (via phaseButtons)
      • Information Panels:
        • Game log/messages
        • Prompt area with decorative background
      • Other Players' Boards for reference

      Interactive Features:

      • Tile Selection:
        • Only active when tilesClickable is true
        • Tracks selected tiles in cmdCoords list
        • Visual feedback through opacity changes
        • Excludes tiles marked in excludedTiles
      • Game Board Preview:
        • Shows the main game board in a modal window

      Layout Organization:

      • Left: Card display and game log
      • Center: Statistics and player board
      • Right: Other players' boards
      • Responsive design bound to primaryStage dimensions

    • phaseChanged

      public void phaseChanged(@NotNull @NotNull PhaseEvent event)
      Handles game phase transitions by updating the player's state and refreshing the UI. This callback method is invoked whenever the game progresses to a new phase.

      Key responsibilities:

      • Updates the player's state with the new phase information
      • Triggers a UI refresh to display the appropriate screen for the new phase
      • Handles special cases for login phase and flight phase reconnection

      Behavior details:

      • Delegates state update to playerClient.setPlayerState()
      • Requests UI refresh through playerClient.showGame() with the printer
      • Prints debug information about the new state class
      • For login phase transitions, calls goToFirstScene() to reset the UI
      • When reconnecting during flight phase, resets flags and shows flight scene
      Specified by:
      phaseChanged in interface View
      Parameters:
      event - The phase change event containing:
      • The new client state (stateClient)
      • Phase transition metadata
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if event is null (enforced by @NotNull annotation)

    • exceptionOccurred

      public void exceptionOccurred(ExceptionEvent exceptionEvent)
      Handles exceptions by displaying an error dialog and resetting any pending tile selections. This method provides user-friendly error reporting and cleans up the UI state when exceptions occur.

      Key functionality:

      • Resets visual state of any selected tiles (sets opacity back to 1)
      • Clears the command coordinates collection
      • Displays a modal error dialog with the exception message
      • Ensures all UI operations are performed on the JavaFX Application Thread

      UI Behavior:

      • Creates a modal dialog titled "Exception"
      • Displays the exception message in a centered label
      • Provides an "Ok" button to dismiss the dialog
      • Blocks interaction with the parent window until dismissed
      Specified by:
      exceptionOccurred in interface View
      Parameters:
      exceptionEvent - The exception event containing:
      • The exception that occurred

    • effectCard

      public void effectCard(LogEvent event)
      Handles card effect events by updating the game log and managing visual effects. This method processes game events that trigger visual changes on the board, particularly shot animations and flight phase transitions.

      Key functionality:

      • Adds event messages to the game log (displayed in reverse chronological order)
      • Manages transition to flight phase when flight starts
      • Handles shot animations with directional rendering
      • Cleans up previous shot effects before applying new ones

      Visual Effects Handling:

      • Shot animations are positioned and rotated based on direction:
        • 0 (left): Rotated 90° from right edge
        • 1 (up): Rotated 180° from bottom edge
        • 2 (right): Rotated 270° from left edge
        • 3 (down): Standard orientation from top edge
      • Different shot types (small/large) use different image sizes
      • Previous shots are automatically removed before new ones are placed
      Specified by:
      effectCard in interface View
      Parameters:
      event - The LogEvent containing:
      • Message to display in log
      • Optional coordinates for shot effects (x, y)
      • Shot type (0-3 indicating size and style)
      • Direction (0-3 indicating cardinal direction)

    • updatePBInfo

      public void updatePBInfo(PBInfoEvent event)
      Updates player board statistics with the latest game state information in a thread-safe manner. This method synchronizes player board metrics between the game engine and JavaFX UI, ensuring all updates occur on the JavaFX Application Thread.

      Maintains and updates the following player statistics:

      • Attack Power (Plasma drills: totAtk)
      • Energy Reserves (totEnergy)
      • Movement Capability (Engine power: totSpeed)
      • Crew Status (Human count: totHumans)
      • Ship Integrity (Damage taken: totDamages)
      • Financial Resources (Credits: totCredits)
      Specified by:
      updatePBInfo in interface View
      Parameters:
      event - The PBInfoEvent containing:
      • plasmaDrillsPower - Current attack strength
      • energy - Available energy units
      • enginePower - Movement capacity
      • numHumans - Surviving crew members
      • damage - Accumulated damage points
      • credits - Available currency

    • Token

      public void Token(TokenEvent tokenEvent)
      Displays a modal dialog containing the player's unique connection token. This dialog provides the player with their session token for potential reconnection and explains its importance.

      Dialog Features:

      • Title: "Token"
      • Non-editable, non-focusable text field displaying the token
      • Instructional text about token importance
      • OK button to dismiss the dialog
      • Window-modal to parent stage

      Visual Design:

      • Clean, transparent text field for token display
      • Consistent 15px font for instructional text
      • 19px font for the token itself
      • Centered alignment of all elements
      • Fixed 350x150 pixel window size
      Specified by:
      Token in interface View
      Parameters:
      tokenEvent - The TokenEvent containing:
      • token - The unique connection token string

    • goToFirstScene

      public void goToFirstScene()
      Resets the game state and displays the initial title screen. This method performs a complete application reset and prepares the UI for a new game session.

      Key Responsibilities:

      • State Reset:
        • Clears all game state variables and collections
        • Reinitializes UI components to default states
        • Resets all game flags (e.g., amIBuilding, killing, etc.)
      • UI Initialization:
        • Creates title screen with game logo
        • Sets up the "Start!" button with lobby navigation
        • Configures responsive layout binding

      Visual Elements:

      • Large "GALAXY TRUCKERS" title with gold styling
      • Centered "Start!" button with large font
      • Responsive layout that adapts to window size

      Determines if the game has started based on the current card image and the building state.
      Returns:
      true if the game has started (indicated by a non-null current card image or if not in

    • baseState

      public void baseState()
      Initializes and sets up the base state of the game's user interface. This method configures the layout, initializes buttons and their functionalities, clears relevant data structures, and prepares the interface for the next phase of the game. The method includes the following functionalities: - Creates "Ready" and "Quit" buttons and their respective event handlers. - Updates the UI to display the current status of players and provide interaction options. - Clears selection-related data and resets associated game state variables, such as disabling tile interactivity and resetting flags for specific actions like killing and theft. - Configures the "Ready" button to enqueue a "Ready" command when clicked. - Configures the "Quit" button to prompt a confirmation dialog. If confirmed, it enqueues a "Quit" command. - Adjusts the UI to transition to the next phase when all players are ready. This method ensures that the game is reset to a neutral "base" state, awaiting players' input for the next actions in the game.

    • killing

      public void killing()
      Executes the process of a "killing" action in the application. This method updates the user interface to allow the user to select crew members to "kill" and triggers the corresponding command execution. The method adjusts UI components like the prompt text, phase buttons, and image views of the crew members. It sets up a button event handler that captures the selections made by the user, generates a command string with the selected coordinates, outputs it to the console, and adds it to an input queue. The method ensures the proper execution of the functionality by running its operations on the JavaFX application thread using `Platform.runLater`.

    • defend

      public void defend(String command, String txt)
      Manages the defend phase of the game by adding buttons for actions such as "Defend!" and "Do Nothing". Updates the user interface and handles user input accordingly.
      Parameters:
      command - The initial command to be used or modified during the defend phase logic.
      txt - The prompt text to be displayed to the user during the defend phase.

    • consumingEnergy

      public void consumingEnergy()
      Handles the action of consuming energy in the current game state. This method sets up the user interface

    • giveTiles

      public void giveTiles(String command, String txt, boolean chunk)
      Handles the interaction logic for giving tiles in the current game phase. This method updates the UI components, handles user inputs via buttons, and processes the selected tiles based on the provided parameters.
      Parameters:
      command - The base command string that will be sent as user input after processing.
      txt - The text to display in the prompt for the current interaction.
      chunk - A boolean indicating whether chunk selection mode is enabled.

    • choosingPlanet

      public void choosingPlanet()
      Displays a UI that allows the user to select a planet to explore or choose to do nothing. This method initializes a ComboBox containing a list of planets and updates the UI elements accordingly. It also defines actions for the "Select" and "Do Nothing" buttons. The "Select" button is disabled unless the user selects a planet from the ComboBox. When the "Select" button is clicked, the method maps the selected planet to a corresponding numeric index and adds the choice to the input queue. Clicking the "Do Nothing" button adds a default negative choice to the input queue. This method dynamically modifies the UI components using a JavaFX `Platform.runLater` block to ensure the UI update is performed on the JavaFX Application Thread.

    • acceptState

      public void acceptState()
      Handles the "accept or decline" state by updating the user interface and setting actions for the provided buttons. This method modifies the current UI elements to display the state where the user is prompted to either accept or decline a choice, and their input is added to a queue. The method updates: - The current card image displayed on the UI. - The prompt text shown to the user. - The buttons displayed, as well as their respective actions. The "Accept" button enqueues an "Accept" command into the input queue when clicked. The "Decline" button enqueues a "Decline" command into the input queue when clicked. This method ensures that the UI updates and associated event-handling are executed on the JavaFX Application Thread.

    • handleCargo

      public void handleCargo()
      Manages the cargo-handling phase within the application. This method sets the appropriate UI components and logic for allowing users to move, select, discard, or finish handling their cargo. The cargo component interacts with the game board and updates the state of rewards and input queues based on user actions. The method accomplishes the following actions: - Updates the current card image and resets cargo-related state variables. - Configures interactive buttons for completing, discarding, or unselecting cargo. - Sets up the stack pane containing the cargo slot and its draggable image representation. - Dynamically creates clickable reward boxes based on available rewards, allowing users to select which reward they wish to place and where. - Updates grid tiles to handle user interactions for placing selected rewards while enforcing certain restrictions for excluded tiles. - Manages the appearance of phase-specific buttons and dynamically modifiable UI components. This method uses the JavaFX `Platform.runLater` to ensure updates to the UI components are made within the JavaFX Application Thread. Preconditions: - `curCard`, `curCardImg`, and other relevant UI components must be properly initialized. - `rewards`, `excludedTiles`, `myBoard`, and other related game state variables must contain valid, up-to-date data. Postconditions: - Cargo handling UI and logic will be active, enabling interaction with rewards and grid tiles. - The state of `rewardsLeft`, input queues, and cargo indices will be updated based on user actions.

    • handleTheft

      public void handleTheft()
      Handles the theft event within the application. This method updates the UI components on the JavaFX application thread to reflect the changes resulting from a theft scenario. Specifically: - Sets the current card image using the provided `curCardImg`. - Updates the internal theft status to `true`. - Displays a prompt message instructing the user to select cargo to give. - Ensures the primaryStage is visible to the user. This method ensures that all UI updates are executed correctly on the JavaFX thread.

    • waiting

      public void waiting()
      Updates the user interface to indicate a waiting state for the user's turn. This method performs the UI updates on the JavaFX Application Thread using the Platform.runLater() mechanism. During this state, interactions are disabled, and specific states are reset. The actions performed in this method include: - Setting the prompt text to indicate the waiting status. - Updating the current card image. - Clearing any buttons related to the game phase. - Disabling tile interactions and specific gameplay actions, such as killing, theft, and chunk selection. - Ensuring the primary stage is displayed to the user.
